item.title: Kremlin Signals Putin-Trump Call Made Little Progress on Ukraine
item.description: Russian President Vladimir Putin and Donald Trump discussed Ukraine in phone talks on Thursday, with the Kremlin indicating that little progress was made in the US president’s efforts to bring an end to the war.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Halpin

media:content.media:description: Ukrainian first responders at the sites of the Russian attack in Kyiv, on June 17. Photographer: Ori Aviram/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Bessent Says Trump to Decide on Any Extension of July 9 Tariff Deadline
item.description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said that President Donald Trump will make the call on any extension of talks with trading partners past the July 9 deadline for higher tariff rates to kick back in.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent, US treasury secretary, during a Bloomberg Television interview in New York, US, on Monday, June 30, 2025. Bessent indicated it wouldn’t make sense for the government to ramp up sales of longer-term securities given where yields are today, though he held out hope that interest rates across maturities will be falling as inflation slows.

item.title: Iran to Keep Cooperating With IAEA Amid Reports of US Talks
item.description: Iran will continue to engage with the United Nations’ nuclear watchdog, Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi said, amid unconfirmed reports that he plans to meet with US Special Envoy Steve Witkoff next week.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Sykes, Vincent Lee

media:content.media:description: Abbas Araghchi

item.title: Trump Call With Putin Underway as US Seeks Ukraine Truce
item.description: US President Donald Trump began a call to Russian leader Vladimir Putin on Thursday, the latest step in his effort to broker an end to the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Lucey

media:content.media:description: A soldier adjusts the aim of a Caesar self-propelled gun near the eastern front line of Ukraine on June 9.

item.title: Zelenskiy to Discuss Halt in US Weapon Deliveries With Trump
item.description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy said he’s likely to speak with Donald Trump as early as Friday following the US decision to halt the transfer of artillery rounds and air defenses to Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Daryna Krasnolutska, Olesia Safronova

media:content.media:description: A worker moves 155mm artillery shells on the production shop at the Scranton Army Ammunition Plant in Scranton, Pennsylvania.

item.title: Who Won and Lost in Trump’s Tax Bill
item.description: Business investors and wealthy Americans are among the biggest winners in President Donald Trump’s tax bill. Those hit the hardest by the sweeping package include elite universities, who face new levies, and immigrants.
item.dc:creator: Jamie Tarabay, Steven T. Dennis

media:content.media:description: The US Capitol in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, June 11, 2025. Senate Republicans intend to propose revised tax and health-care provisions to President Donald Trump's $3 trillion signature economic package this week, shrugging off condemnations of the legislation by Elon Musk as they rush to enact it before July 4. Photographer: Eric Lee/Bloomberg

item.title: Colombia’s Foreign Minister Quits, Deepening Petro’s Woes
item.description: Colombian Foreign Minister Laura Sarabia quit on Thursday, the latest in a series of high-profile defections to shake the leftist administration of President Gustavo Petro.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Medina, Andrea Jaramillo

media:content.media:description: Laura Sarabia Photographer: Ivan Valencia/Bloomberg

item.title: BRICS Aspires to Occupy Global Ground Vacated by US Under Trump
item.description: Ever since BRICS was founded more than a decade ago, the group of emerging-market nations has struggled to identify a common purpose. President Donald Trump’s tariffs may have solved that problem.
item.dc:creator: Simone Iglesias, S'thembile Cele, Martha Viotti Beck

media:content.media:description: Flags of the original BRICS.

item.title: Russian Internet Outages Soar as Kremlin Boosts War Controls
item.description: Russia is regularly switching off mobile internet connections in large swaths of the country for security reasons, in a sign of the Kremlin’s growing ability to control popular access to technology.
item.dc:creator: Laura Avetisyan

media:content.media:description: A woman uses her mobile phone at an observation point in Nizhny Novgorod, Russia.

item.title: Democrat Jeffries Delays House Vote on Trump Tax Bill With Marathon Speech
item.description: House Democratic Leader Hakeem Jeffries is blocking a final vote on Republicans’ tax and spending package with a lengthy floor speech bashing the bill.
item.dc:creator: Maeve Sheehey, Jonathan Tamari, Greg Giroux

media:content.media:description: WASHINGTON, DC - JULY 02: House Minority Leader Rep. Hakeem Jeffries (D-NY), joined by fellow Democrats, speaks out against the One, Big, Beautiful Bill Act at a press conference outside of the U.S. Capitol on July 02, 2025 in Washington, DC. House Republicans continue their work to pass the Senate version of The One, Big, Beautiful Bill Act, President Trump's sweeping tax and spending bill. (Photo by Kevin Dietsch/Getty Images)

item.title: Zimbabwe Ruling Party Adds Sanctioned Tycoon to Leadership Ranks
item.description: Zimbabwe’s ruling party added sanctioned tycoon Kudakwashe Tagwirei to its highest decision-making body, a move that could further strain relations with the US and other Western nations.
item.dc:creator: Godfrey Marawanyika, Ray Ndlovu

media:content.media:description: Kudakwashe Tagwirei

item.title: Bill Ackman Backs Adams in NYC Mayor's Race
item.description: Billionaire investor Bill Ackman called on Andrew Cuomo to step aside from the New York City mayoral race and allow incumbent Eric Adams to take on democratic socialist Zohran Mamdani in November.
item.dc:creator: Nacha Cattan, Natalie Wong, Laura Nahmias

media:content.media:description: Eric Adams on the steps of City Hall in New York, US, on June 26.

item.title: Chip Design Software Makers Win US Reprieve in China Trade Deal
item.description: President Donald Trump’s administration has lifted recent export license requirements for chip design software sales in China, as Washington and Beijing implement a trade deal for both countries to ease some restrictions on critical technologies.
item.dc:creator: Mackenzie Hawkins

media:content.media:description: Siemens AG. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Visits Iowa While 2028 Republicans Wait for Their Chance
item.description: President Donald Trump’s visit to Iowa on Thursday is ostensibly to kick off a yearlong celebration leading up to America’s 250th anniversary. But his trip also casts a spotlight on the intense dynamics of his nascent second term as well as questions over who will barnstorm the critical state come 2028 as his successor.
item.dc:creator: Akayla Gardner

media:content.media:description: Children's drawings are taped to a wall at the Campaign Headquarters of US President Donald Trump in Urbandale, Iowa, in January 2024. Photographer: Jim Watson/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Cartel Money Crackdown Has Mexican Banks Reeling From Sanctions
item.description: Top bank executives gathered at a luxury resort off Mexico’s Pacific coast encountered an unexpected guest at an annual convention in May. A high-level official with the US Treasury Department had flown down to the soiree — where rooms ran as much as $900 a night — to deliver a firm warning.
item.dc:creator: Michael O'Boyle, Eric Martin

media:content.media:description: Intercam Banco headquarters in Mexico City. Photographer: Stephania Corpi/Bloomberg

item.title: Curtis Sliwa Says He Won’t Quit NYC Mayor’s Race Unless ‘Hit by a Mack Truck’
item.description: Curtis Sliwa said he won’t drop out of the race for New York mayor, regardless of the pressure applied or incentives offered to the Republican candidate.
item.dc:creator: Laura Nahmias, Gregory Korte

media:content.media:description: Curtis Sliwa

item.title: David Mabuza, Former South African Deputy President, Dies at 64
item.description: David Mabuza, who shrugged off a succession of graft scandals to become South Africa’s deputy president, has died. He was 64.
item.dc:creator: Michael Cohen, Paul Vecchiatto

media:content.media:description: David Mabuza

item.title: Supreme Court to Consider Bans on Trans Athletes in Women’s Sports
item.description: The US Supreme Court agreed to decide whether states can ban transgender girls and women from competing for their schools on female athletic teams, heeding conservative calls to consider further curbing LGBTQ rights.
item.dc:creator: Greg Stohr

media:content.media:description: Demonstrators with Gender Liberation Movement display a transgender pride flag outside the US Supreme Court in Washington, DC.

item.title: Supreme Court Refuses to Require Parent Consent for Abortion
item.description: The US Supreme Court turned away a new effort to restrict abortion, declining to hear arguments that parents have a constitutional right to prevent their underage child from ending a pregnancy.
item.dc:creator: Greg Stohr

media:content.media:description: The examination room in women’s health clinic in Jacksonville, Florida.

item.title: Immigrant Groups Switch Tactics to Fight Trump Birthright Limits
item.description: Immigrant-rights groups and Democratic-led states challenging President Donald Trump’s limits on birthright citizenship have changed their strategies after a Supreme Court decision upended their initial legal victories.
item.dc:creator: Erik Larson

media:content.media:description: Demonstrators outside the US Supreme Court in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, May 15, 2025. The US Supreme Court is considering whether to allow President Donald Trumps executive order restricting the longstanding concept of birthright citizenship to start taking effect while a lawsuit proceeds.

item.title: US House Nears Passage of Trump’s Tax Bill After All-Nighter
item.description: The US House of Representatives is on track to pass Donald Trump’s tax and spending bill Thursday, allowing lawmakers to meet the president’s self-imposed July 4 deadline after negotiating all night long.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Steven T. Dennis, Ken Tran, Jack Fitzpatrick

media:content.media:description: House Speaker Mike Johnson in the Capitol on Wednesday

item.title: Reeves Hails Fiscal Rules After Starmer Backing Calms Markets
item.description: Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves stressed her commitment to fiscal discipline in her management of the UK’s public finances after reassurances about her position from Prime Minister Keir Starmer led jittery markets to rebound on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Joe Mayes, Ellen Milligan, Lucy White

media:content.media:description: Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves, left, with Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer, right, and Health Secretary Wes Streeting in Stratford, London, on July 3. Photographer: Jack Hill/The Times/EMPPL PA Wire

item.title: Vietnam Still Finalizing Trade Deal Already Announced by Trump
item.description: Vietnam said negotiators are still working to finalize the details of the trade deal announced by US President Donald Trump, providing little clarity to businesses and investors beyond the tariff rates disclosed so far.
item.dc:creator: Nguyen Dieu Tu Uyen, Nguyen Xuan Quynh

media:content.media:description: Operations at the Tan Vu Terminal at Haiphong Port in Haiphong, Vietnam.

item.title: Israel Pushes to Gain Ground in Gaza as Hamas Weighs Ceasefire
item.description: Israel is intensifying military operations in one of the last Hamas strongholds in Gaza, as the sides stake out positions before ceasefire negotiations proposed by US President Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Fares Alghoul, Dan Williams

media:content.media:description: Israeli soldiers work on tanks at a staging area near the border with Gaza on July 1. Photographer: Ariel Schalit/AP Photo

item.title: Tracking Every Trump Tariff and Its Economic Effect
item.description: For the full experience visit: Tracking Every Trump Tariff and Its Economic Effect
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Diamond, Adrian Leung, Jane Pong, Christopher Udemans, Jason Kao

item.title: Investors See Way for Milei to End Fight Over State Oil Company
item.description: There is a silver lining for Javier Milei in a multibillion-dollar US judgment targeting Argentina’s main oil producer: At least some investors see the libertarian leader as having a shot at finally putting an end to a long-running legal saga.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Tobias, Kevin Simauchi

media:content.media:description: A YPF storage terminal in Ushuaia, Argentina.

item.title: German Coalition Resists Calls for Wider Electricity-Tax Cut
item.description: German Chancellor Friedrich Merz’s ruling coalition rebuffed calls to expand an electricity-tax discount to include households and additional companies, saying they’ll only do so when they have “financial leeway.”
item.dc:creator: Kamil Kowalcze

media:content.media:description: Chancellor Friedrich Merz, right, and Finance Minister Lars Klingbeil.

item.title: Merz Rules Out Pooled Deposit Protection in Banking Union Blow
item.description: Chancellor Friedrich Merz rejected the idea of joint European Union deposit insurance, a scheme large banks and many officials view as key to forging closer financial ties and ultimately strengthening the sovereignty of the bloc.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Comfort, Michael Nienaber

media:content.media:description: German Chancellor Friedrich Merz on July 3. Photographer: Sean Gallup/Getty Images

item.title: Russian Navy’s Deputy Commander Gudkov Killed During Combat
item.description: A high-ranking Russian navy commander was killed on Wednesday, one of the most senior military casualties since the start of the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Greg Sullivan

media:content.media:description: Russian sailors carry a naval flag a naval parade rehearsal in central Saint Petersburg.

item.title: Powell Silence on His Future Complicates Trump Fed Chair Search
item.description: As President Donald Trump and his advisers begin weighing replacements for Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell, they’re running into one significant complication: It’s not clear that Powell will leave the US central bank next year.
item.dc:creator: Saleha Mohsin, Joshua Green, Amara Omeokwe

media:content.media:description: Jerome Powell Photographer: Al Drago/Bloomberg
